author: Chonkway

description.text: After John made the very nice clip on fan mount for his Maker Gear Mosaic, he mentioned that it could be parametric in OpenSCAD, so I thought I would take a shot at making such a version. It's no were near as nice looking as the original, but smooth curves like that are tough in OpenSCAD... at least for me.

This is the first thing I've posted and the second thing I've ever designed in OpenSCAD so it's probably buggy. Check everything before wasting plastic and time on making it. Let me know if you find a problem. fanmout2.scad corrects bugs and adds rounding as per Hanks suggestion. I attempted to intersect the base with a larger circle to remove unnecessary material the base and make it more like Johns original, but couldn't figure out the translate required to make it correct for a reasonable range of parameters. Another day... Tried to upload a new picture to show the roundiness but that doesn't seem to want to work on the site today. FanWidth = 89; //the width of the fan. Used to set the length of the base.
FanID = FanWidth-4; //Inside diameter of the fan. Typically just a few less than the width.
BoltClear = 2; //size of a clearance hole for the mounting bolts
BoltInset = 5; //how far the fan mounting holes are inset from the edge of the fan
LipWidth = 5; //the width of the lip over which the mount will be set.
//this controls the size of the gap between the "clamp" and the edge of the fan.
LipDepth = 20; //the depth of the far edge of the lip. This sets the size of the clamp back
ClampWidth = 5; //the thickness of the material used to make the mount.
Rounding = 4; //the amount to round the corners.
FaceAngle = 0.1; //decrease for smoother curves, increase for faster rendering.

comments.text: If you want smooth curves on the object, there are two things you can do in OpenSCAD to improve this model.  First, on the two large clrcles (cylinders), specific a smaller face angle ($fa=1) to make the cylinders smoother (but slower to render).  Secondly, use the Minkowski Sum to merge the base with a small cylinder to round the outside edges:
comments.author: Hank-Cowdog

comments.text: Neat! Thanks Hank, I'll incorporate those suggestions. I was thinking about intersecting the base with a /really/ big cylinder to curve it in the same way the part this is derived from is curved. Can I combine the minkowski with an intersected part?
comments.author: Hank-Cowdog

comments.text: minkowski is just like union, difference, translate, etc.: you should be able to perform a minkowski sum on some objects, then intersect that solid with another solid (or compound solid).
comments.author: JamesNewton

get a sneak peak on my latest works in progress on patreon



Additional shell design stls available here.

This 3d printed turtle uses the same flex concept from my Mini Monster Truck to create legs that allow the toy to bounce and scurry around when tapped. The head can also retract into the shell.

Check out my process for designing this thing here

The model assembles with the printed H-Clips and needs no glue. The parts print without the need for supports.

If you are interested in my design process and latest 3d printing experiments, check out my website and my Twitter.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YMq4T2ZYYQ&feature=youtu.be

1fQi4dO1prnjXr39rZPYfA+DRmnLvrtjF/Kk7N7JbSMn75r5PkDlyWWg8HoGum7l2
YoVxy1t9e2q76JUZKMYHA====



This design will probably not work with a brim unless you spend time sanding and cleaning up the edges at the base of the print. This will stick the springs together and make the center channel for the head narrower. Using a raft might also affect this.

If you are having trouble with the head sliding, I have uploaded 3 head files with the stem portion scaled to be narrower:
Head95.stl - 95% original width
Head9.stl - 90% original width
Head85.stl - 85% original width
refer to the video to see the assembly process.

title: Magni-Card-A (Magnifying Glass Object Holder)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter is midway through her Occupational Therapy Assisting program and she was tasked with designing an adaptive technology that would assist people with disabilities. With a 99 year old great-grandmother with failing eyesight, who still enjoys playing cards in mind, she thought of designing a holder for the trump card.

Since I had the skills and the 3D printer, I volunteered both so that it wasn't a cardboard and tape production. Perhaps someone will find it usefull for something.

The clamp fits a CARSON FreeHand LED Magnifier, 2.5x/5x, found at Office Depot, and attaches in a way that it allows for the stand to close and for the light switch to turn on and off.

This could be used for a lot more than holding a trump card. With a small alligator clip or other attachments, it could provide help in holding and magnifying small things that are being soldered, glued or otherwise worked on. I made one of the holding arms in two parts so that designing new holders would use less plastic and be swapable.

The holding arms were designed to use this thing to hold the card, simply because it worked and I had one lying around: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635200

My time and PLA went into designing this thing. If this design blesses your life in some way, feel free to favor me with a tip as thanks. Gratuities are not required, but are definitely appreciated. You can tip me any amount that you would like here: https://www.paypal.me/brysonjack
Make sure to include a comment telling me which design it is. Thanks in advance.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The clamps for the handle were printed at .1mm I believe, and the back clamp was printed upside down like I have it in the .stl file. The rest of the parts can be printed .2mm or whatever you prefer.

You will need a hobby knife and needle file set to clean up the print and get the clamp to fit together. Don't force things or it may break. File until it joins together without much effort. Hold the front clamp in place and then slide the back clamp down over the top of the front clamp.

You will need 2 bolts and 2 wingnuts for assembly. We used (2) #6-32 Stainless Steel Standard (SAE) Forged Wing Nuts and (2) #6-32 x 3/4 inch bolts, both by Hillman, from Lowes.

description.text: When printed please take time to sand down or file down the edge of the vial, not the lid, just the vial's outer edge because if you try to put it together and close it it will lock on you because when printing 3D the lines may be sticking out(you can hit up the inner of the lid if you really need too)...the fraction sticking out is micro, but will lock the lid on and will be hard to remove because the measurements were so on point...so please use sand paper or a file to take a bit off the rough edges and enjoy stashing away for the trip ;)...
CCSS

The Bottle Stash I made this vial in attempts to create somthing i can throw stuff into without making it super big or clunky. This size is perfect for putting anything from pills to small trinkets like guitar pics to your favorite superhero rings...being my first design i am in love with it.

time consuming... This will take roughly about 5 -7 hours...i ran the 3D printer at 50mm/s 100mm....and 154% speed, not 100 but 154%, made for quicker printings, also enable support cooling or use a fan to cool print and use no support just raft and a 10mm rim to prevent warping and the extruder head from nocking it over or what not..

you will need a 3D printer and filament material for printing and a file or sandpaper to shave off a bit off the outer edge of the vial itself in order to prevent the lid from jamming shut...it will be hard to get back off so PLEASE file down the outer edge smooth, also may need too smooth out the lid inner walls that rub on the vial itself, also get under the slider part that holds lid close...on the print if no supports were used(supports not needed for this print, but keep in mind that the slider part is an overhang and for it to not hang the first layer you must use support cooling, so a cooling fan will be needed if no support used...

print_settings.Notes:: Print both parts at once using the file ShoeKlips.stl.  If you want to print the parts individually those files are also available.  Remember that you'll probably need a pair of these ;)

description.text:
This is a design inspired by Pentland_Designs' "Shoelace Locks". While I like the concept I found their original design to be overly complex and very dependent on tight printer tolerances. This is my take on it.

Use ShoeKlips to easily and quickly secure shoelaces without needing to tie or untie knots. The ShoeKlips clip together easily with one hand and also release easily with one hand. When released the clip will not undo itself all the way but rather stop on a second internal catch. This second catch is sloped so if you do need to completely undo the ShoeKlips you can by wiggling the two sections apart.

https://youtu.be/4ZtgjKszHLg

20/04/2017 Update: I've added a second type of Klip Arms with the tips more severely rounded. I found that on some print settings with PLA those points were still coming out too pointy which meant they could poke you in the finger when closing the klips. You can quickly round the tips off but why have extra processing. With this newer version they are even more rounded and should always be comfortable to use.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print both parts at once using the file ShoeKlips.stl. If you want to print the parts individually those files are also available. Remember that you'll probably need a pair of these ;)

Lacing it up

Once printed add the ShoeKlips to your shoes like shown here.

You'll notice the arm part is thicker on one side near the lace holes. The ShoeKlips will work either way but they look cleaner if you put them on with the thick side facing out.

On step 4 lace feed the lace back into the middle hole which will give a clean look and cause the lace to clutch on itself. You can feed the leftover lace between the tongue of the shoe and the rest of the laces. You can also add a knot to prevent the lace from loosening but I haven't found that to be necessary.
This is a design inspired by Pentland_Designs' "Shoelace Locks", redesigned from scratch in Fusion 360.

comments.text: Ahh.  You are likely over-extruding.  A symptom of over extrusion is that holes are too small and the outside perimeter of objects are too large. This combines in prints like this to make the fit between parts really tight.  Try reducing your flow rate a few %.

description.text:
This is a five round speed loader for .38 Special or .357 Magnum. It was designed specifically for my Taurus 605 but should fit any revolver with a J Frame. (so I've read)

I tried a commercial speed loader but it hit the grip so it wouldn't work. I designed this one so one side was flat so it would fit without hitting. It takes some practice to line it up right still but it's better than nothing.

There are only three pieces to the speed loader and it is held together with a single 6/32 x1/2" button head screw. I tapped the hole before inserting the screw but you might be able to just self thread it in.

The lock has to be inserted correctly for it to work properly. It will fit in four separate ways but it will only work correctly in two of the positions so a little trial and error might be in order.

If the lock is inserted in one of the correct ways turning the knob clockwise will release the shells. If you prefer it to release with a counter clock wise twist like me just reverse it 180° when putting it together.

The nubs on the lock may wear out after time I haven't tested it that much yet.

There are two versions of the Body a Flat Side and a Round one. There is also two versions of the Lock. A single piece version and I've included a two piece version with several Knobs with different logos on top just for fun. (Super glue the two pieces together after printing.)

5-14-17 - I reuploaded the STL of the Retainer. (It seemed some slicers where having problems with the last one so hopefully this fixes those issues for people.)

title: Tevo Tarantula LCD Control Wrap-Around
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I like the use of the clear acrylic panels for the mainboard and for the LCD control board. I like to see my electronics (mechanical workings, too). The problem with this, though, is that the sides are exposed. That is very bad for electronics, especially when working with metal tools - forceps, Xacto knife, feeler gauges, calipers, etc... Several times I have come close to shorting out the board by a stray tool or two. My solution? A wrap around. This is designed for ease of use as well as installation. Simply remove the rear plate and slip the wrap around the hex stand-offs. The wrap is hooked on the edges so that it holds itself in place once the rear plate is reattached. The left side is left open for easy access to the SD card and there is a slot at the top (or bottom, depending on how you orient the wrap) for the control wires.

Tevo Tarantula

We built this coin slot to work with a coin door we found here on Thingiverse. We used an IR Emitter/Receiver to allow detection of the coin in the slot. You can watch our build video here: https://youtu.be/iZGhxdxC9DU

How to use this piece:
1) Print it
2) Affix the coin door to a piece of plywood or other material that fits the area you wish to install it.
3) Super-Glue (or other glue) the piece to the slot. If level, the coin will easily slide out. Make sure the "Higher End" is on the coin-door side,the "Lower End" is pointing toward the box that receives the coin.
4) Use a box like the one we found at Lowe's to re-direct the coin to the coin box (see video).
5) For added fun, you can use the instructable mentioned in our video to build an Ir detection device to register the coin insert into your build, light an LED and/or make it blink when a coin is inserted. There may be other options, but this is one that made sense for us.

It was tested with Quarters, Dimes, Nickles and pennies (USD)

This part compliments this awesome coin door build designed by "Big-E"

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Z Threaded Rod Brass Adapters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For some reason the default Prusa i3 designed X Ends (Where the Z Rods Connect) utilize a printed? (Unsure because I cant find the part anywhere) Z Rod connector which I don't personally care for, especially since most Z rods will come with Brass fittings.
I wanted to use the included brass fittings but I didn't want to redesign and reprint the X ends since they are somewhat larger prints, especially at 95% infill.
So I made these little adapters to keep the brass fitting squared up.
You will need to redrill the holes but the stock nut locations will still work with a tiny bit of trimming. The stock parts only use 2 screws so you can drill 2 of the holes with a 2.5mm drill bit then the 2 with nuts using a 3mm drill bit and the screws will grab extremely well with reasonable infill %.
I will likely redesign the Prusa X ends at some point but for now this is my solution and I believe it will work pretty good.

This is a mount for a MEAN WELL SE-450 power supply that mounts onto 20mm aluminum extrusion. This mount is designed to face the power supply fan away from the print bed, to mitigate interference from stray airflow over the print.

It incorporates a mount for a chassis mount AC power cord inlet plug socket with switch fuse (e.g. this one from Amazon). A panel insert separates the AC wiring from the low-voltage while allowing the part to be printed without support.

In addition to a power supply with similar mounting requirements, the receptacle and the mounts, you will need the following:

4 x M4*8mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screws
4 x M4*10mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screws

Wire the receptacle appropriately and allow a short length so that the cover may be attached and removed. Affix the receptacle to the mount with two M4*10mm screws, and glue the divider in place.

Use the shorter screws for the top of the mount and the countersunk holes under the extrusion grooves, and use the longer screws for the other side of the mount.

If necessary, ream out the M5 holes with a 13/64" drill bit. You may need to file the extrusion slot to fit snugly.

Pay very close attention to the labeling when connecting input and output power connections, commodity power supplies often switch arrangements without notice. Also, be mindful of the input power switch! Most of these power supplies ship in the 220 AC input configuration. Be sure to check (and double-check) the setting before power-on.

title: Simple parametric box generator for laser cut

description.text:

You can customize it with the thingiverse customizer.. Actually, if you need a dxf-file, you have to use OpenSCAD.
Note, that the variables for the size are the OUTER-dimensions. If you need defined inner dimensions, add 2x of the material thickness to each side.

author: SharkNado

title: Prusa i3 MK2 / MK2S Y Axis LM8UU Bearing Mounts

description.text:
These are to hold the Y Axis LM8UU bearings into the stock locations but offer 4 mounting screws. This will especially help anyone who cut their own Y Axis from wood or bought a 3rd party Y axis because it ensures all bearings are sitting at the same height.
These are similar to the mounts Tom designed but beefed up and they feature recessed screw heads. The screws required are M3 and the length would be determined by the thickness of your Y Axis. 1/2" thick wood requires a 30mm M3, 6mm thick wood would require a 20mm M3 for standard nuts and 25mm M3 for locknuts.
The best part of this design is that they utilize the stock hole locations so no extra drilling required.

title: Bed handle for Wanhao Di3 / Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

description.text:
Ever burn your finger / hand moving the print bed while it's still hot ? I did, and I printed some bed handle before, but they came off a bit too easily, probably because of the doubleside tape I use don't hold well under heat.

This is a remix of polysquare's and Mechman's bed handle. Like the width of polysquare's design but doesn't fit v2.1; like Mechman's handle height, but the handle is too wide. Merge them together it work, but found the mount isn't 100% secure. Merge it together with my own design which used in the cable chain mount, perfect ! You can push and pull the bed securely.

This bed handle require your Di3 or MakerSelect v2.1 Y-axis plate have a square cut hole. If you don't have that square hole, this is not for you.

Print, snap on and that's it. Don't need tape or screws for it to work. Having said that, I did put some doubleside tape to make it a bit more secure.

Printer:

Maker Select v2.1

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

20%

Notes:

Since the clip on part is pretty fine in detail, you'll want the detail part facing upwards. thus, print the handle up-side down and require heavy use of supports.

With Cura support configration-
Support type = Touching buildplate
Structure type = Lines
Overhang angle for support (deg) = 60
Fill amount (%) = 15
Distance X/Y (mm) = 0.7
Distance Z (mm) = 0.15

"SkyFlea" is a complete 3D-Printed drone based on discontinued 3DR's IRIS+. Together with a Pixhawk flight controller, it is a fully autonomous medium-sized drone.

Maiden flight test : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RZMS9qAsDP8

Plastic parts comprise 3 categories :

(A) Frame.
(B) 2-Axis Gimbal.
(C) Parts printed by using files from other design sources.

(A) Frame
(1) Battery Compartment
(2) Bottom Plate
(3) Top Plate
(4) Top Shell
(5) Front Plate
(6) Rear Plate
(7) LED Lens
(8) LED PCB Retainer
(9) GPS Module Cover
(10) Landing Foot

(B) 2-Axis Gimbal
(11) Bottom Vibration Damping Plate
(12) Top Vibration Damping Plate
(13) Bottom IMU Cover
(14) Top IMU Cover
(15) Roll Arm

(C) Parts printed by using files from other design sources.

Obtained from https://www.myminifactory.com/object/3drobotics-iris-19615 (credit to 3DRobotics IRIS+ by 3DR Robotics)
(16) Arm (iris-Iris-Arm.STL)
(17) Wiring Clip (iris-Iris-Clip.STL)

Obtained from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163472/#files (credit to Omnimac 3DR Pixhawk Anti Vibration Mount by GuyMcCaldin)
(18) Top Pixhawk Vibration Damping Plate (Omnimac_Pixhawk_Mount_v1.1_top_plate.stl)
(19) Bottom Pixhawk Vibration Damping Plate (Omnimac_Pixhawk_Mount_v1.1_bottom_plate.stl)

Tips :

The design intended for drone equipped with components listed below. Different components with similar dimensions and specifications may be used.

Battery compartment can easily house a 3s 40C 6200mAh battery,

Landing foot is taller than original IRIS+'s to clear newly designed battery compartment from ground.

Four micro ESC's, a 50x50mm 2-axis GBC board, an APM/Pixhawk power module, 50x50mm power distribution PCB installed on the Bottom Plate.

Pixhawk flight controller (on vibration damping plate), telemetry radio, FPV transmitter, a piezo buzzer, I2C extender module installed on Top Plate.

GPS module, a receiver with two antennas, an APM/Pixhawk safety switch installed underneath/on the Top Shell.

ฺTo minimize EMF interference, bottom of GPS module should be covered by an EMI-shield cup, made from thin (0.1mm., or less) copper sheet, soldered and wired to battery negative (ground).

Print density : 50%. Reduce print density for lighter weight.

Printer : Delta, 210x210x320mm print volume.

Parts 1-3, 5-6, 8, 10 (2 off), 11-15, 16 (2 off), 17 (12 off), 18-19 printed from black ABS plastic.
Parts 4, 9, 10 (2 off), 16 (2 off) printed from blue ABS plastic.
Part 7 printed from clear PLA plastic.

Part 4 sanded and spray-painted blue for a glossy finish.

Use small rubber balls similar to this : https://hobbyking.com/en_us/vibration-damping-ball-65g-bag-of-8.html for gimbal and flight controller (Pixhawk) vibration damping plates.

Use M3 hex screws for assembly (except for LED/USB port PCB retainer, GPS module cover, and Gimbal IMU cover which are secured in place by small 1.5mm self-tapping screws) .

Use (original, replacement, or printed) Mobius mounting base for mounting the camera onto gimbal top vibration damping plate.

Install M3 brass inserts, 4mm (OD), 3mm (H), in all mounting holes for M3 mounting screws.

Components and Specifications

Frame Type: V-config Quad Copter, 3D Printed with ABS Plastic
MTM lenght : 510mm (diagonal), 260mm (front-rear), 444mm (front-front), 413mm (rear-rear)
Height : 142mm (ground-top)
Flight controller: 1 x Pixhawk Px4 (clone)
GPS: 1 x Rctimer u-blox LEA-6H GPS & MAG V2
Radio: FrSky Taranis Plus X9D transmitter + FrSky D4R-II receiver with TTL-RS232 converter (FrSky FUL-1)
Motor : 4 x MT2212 920Kv
ESC: 4 x Hobbywing XRotor Micro BLHeli 20A 2-4S F396 E
Props: 2 x APC 10x4.7SFP (CW) + 2 x 10x4.7SF (CCW)
Camera : Mobius with C2 Lens and 3D-printed vibration damping plate
Gimbal : 1 x 2-axis Martinez GBC (clone)
Gimbal Motor: 2 x Turnigy 2208
Battery: 1 x 3s 40C 6200mAH
AUW : 1600gm.
Hovering Flight Time : 15 minutes

Yes

Low/Fast (300 um)

22% ?

1) Print it
2) Remove supports
3) Tap holes into bucket with 5/32"=4mm bit (for default 4mm holes, good for #8 bolts/nuts,) using the print as a guide.
4) With the prints in place, trace out the holes in the side of the bucket and the top lid.
5) Cut out the holes
6) Affix the printed parts with bolts
7) Attach top hose to your vaccum/ShopVac.
8) Attach a hose to the side/blow port, this is what will suck up debris

remixed_from.author: supasorn
remixed_from.title: Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula)

title: Folger Tech i3 2020 Nema 17 Extruder Mount (El Scorpion)

description.text:
Version 1 in pictures is WHITE.
Version 2 in pictures is BLUE. I haven't found the time to replace it in RL but you can be assured it works, I tested the fit on a Z-axis motor and it is oooooooooh-soooo-nice. All other important dimensions are coincident with the earlier version so I feel safe posting this now.

EDIT: I finally stuck it on... went on the motor perfectly; though I had to file out the 18mm diameter probe hole a tiny, TINY bit. I had to move the heat-block and throat back up almost all the way to the extruder as the fan ducts no longer go sooo low. So you can disregard moving the hot end down. I keep the instructions here just so newbies like me have a reference in case they need to make an adjustment. Looks pretty good. I'm happy with it.

If you are like me and so many others you (already did or are doing now) shopped around for upgrades to your printer BEFORE you bought one, had a list and made your decision on what to buy based on your upgrade options, bought the thing, put it together and started printing all your upgrades. I had a heck of a time finding my footing at first and the cooling/proximity probe mount points are pretty major aspects I simply could not fix without spending a bunch of cash and just replacing the extruder with a higher quality one... on a printer I just freaking bought. And even if I bought a better extruder I still needed to print new parts for it... so I made dun dun DUN!!!!! El Scorpion.... This part will help you if you are getting ready to print Toranado parts OR just want something that works.

This is an extruder mount for the Folger Tech i3 2020 direct drive extruder. I remixed this from 2 other "things", the Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula) bysupasorn and a proximity probe mount for the nema 17 direct drive extruder that I can't, for the life of me, find anymore to give credit to (SORRY YO). Either way, I had to almost completely remake the whole thing because the dimensions were all wrong or the walls were too thin or this, that; the idea was spawned from these two things and the fact that the Folger Tech i3 2020 direct drive extruder is difficult to find "accessories" for because of the limited mount options... that I found, anyway.

I had a cooling fan hitting below the nozzle from the front but found that my printed walls were not very smooth as cooling from one direction was not even as the y-axis moved the bed back and forth; the layer being laid down in the +y direction would not get any cooling but the layer laid down in the -y direction would get a bunch. After I made the first prototype (WHITE ABOVE) my prints looked uniform and good at 0.1 layer height with .4mm nozzle. Even if you don't use this puppy I highly recommend using a 360 fan duct or some other multi-angle blower.

The original dual blower duct fan thingy was awesome because both fans were bringing in air from the outside as they faced away from each other.

The El Scorpion is made for the following accessories:
2 50mm BLOWER fans
1 18mm proximity probe

Requires no hard-points as it mounts directly on the nema 17 motor. I guess you can use this on any direct drive extruder where the nema 17 faces forward.

The El Scorpion uses this hardware to fully construct:
4 50mm 3m socket cap screws
4 3m nylock nuts
2 small screws to mount each of the blowers (1 each) even though it is a snug fit into each duct

The fans plug into the ducts pretty snug but will line up with the anchor points differently so you will have to drill a pilot hole for each screw (I left plenty of room for error on each anchor point) but this is really a 30 second job and 2 screws in your junk drawer or misc screw bucket. Whatever works just don't crack the PLA. Yeah, I used PLA for its stiffness because of the proximity probe. This puppy will keep it stable and unmoving.

***The X-axis end-stop (which I keep on the right-hand side) will need to be moved to the upper 8mm smooth rod and then bent down at an angle to allow the carriage to hit it. Also, remove the two screws holding the end-stop to the 8mm rod clip, move the pcb up one hole and screw it on tight; 1 screw is all you need anyway 8)

Yeah, that's about it. In the original design I had to "bend" the nema 17 bracket apart to slide it on and then it would break. So now we have this puppy.

Printer:

Folger Tech i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

60-100 up to you

Notes:

PLA for stiffness. Triangle supports at 4 or 5mm. Print the LOWER part up-side up. Print the UPPER part up-side down. Make sure the support Z-distance is at least 0.2mm as any less and you will have a heck of a time removing the very little support INSIDE the fan duct.

The print at 0.1mm layer height takes a while, but it looks soooooooo good. Take your time removing the supports. I used an exacto knife and needle-nosed pliers.... gently now.

YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE TO REMOVE OR UNBOLT THE EXTRUDER TO MOUNT THIS!!! BLAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!

Take a breath, yeah I know it's pretty awesome.

HOWEVER, the ducts go pretty low from where the original nozzle lays on the vanilla setup.... sooooo upon mounting El Scorpion you will need to remove the fan and heat-sink in order to get to the block to loosen the set screw that is holding the heat-break (throat) in place in order to lower it to its LOWEST POSITION POSSIBLE. So here's what you do:

***These instructions are for novice makers like myself that are new to the 3D printing game and have a Folger Tech i3 2020. Please don't be offended at how simplistic, basic, or even childish the instructions are.... I wouldn't care anyway 8)

*We are starting off with a COLD hot-end here, people, we aren't barbarians***

  1. Pull the 2 screws at the bottom of the fan, the block is only being held up by the filament inside the heat-break at this point, don't worry it's not witchcraft.

  2. Cut the filament above the extruder, squeeze the extruder button thingy to release the filament and pull the block away from the extruder.

  3. Heat the hot-end to PLA-melting-temp and pull the filament from the throat (USE ALL PRECAUTIONS TO KEEP YOURSELF FROM GETTING BURNED AND YOUR BED DAMAGED OR ANYTHING ELSE GOING UP IN FLAMES!!).

  4. Cool the hot-end... use the fan 'er sumtin.

5.Loosen the set screw holding the throat to the block (AND BY BLOCK I MEAN THE BIG PIECE OF METAL THAT WAS SCREWED TO THE MOTOR, NOT THE PIECE THE NOZZLE IS CONNECTED TO). Looking through the top of the block, lower the throat to its lowest point where the set screw still hits the throat and then screw the set screw in tight with an eye on the orientation of the heat-block (nozzle piece). If you leave the heat cartridge wires on the left they will come up and behind the left-side blower anchor. You'll see.

  1. Without attaching the heat-sink and extruder-fan, put the screws back in the block and put a few turns on them to lock the block into a height.

  2. Now look at where the bottom of your nozzle lays in comparison with the fan ducts. You want the bottom of the fan ducts to be slightly ABOVE the bottom of the nozzle.... or your ducts will crash into the bed and into all of your prints and bla bla bla. If you need to adjust the throat position then do yo thang. DON'T FRET ABOUT THE BLOWERS HITTING THE NOZZLE AT THIS POINT. DADDY HAS YOU COVERED. JUST KEEP GOOOOING, JUST KEEP GOOOOING.

  3. Pull the screws and use the Kapton tape that came with your printer to wrap the block attached directly to the nozzle. You want to wrap the block and just below it without getting too low.

  4. Put the screws back into the block and a couple turns into the motor, no heat-sink or fan, feed some filament through and get it into the throat and down to the nozzle. Pull the screws and put it all back together.... tight.

  5. Now your nozzle is at the correct height in relation to the fan ducts. All you got to worry about now is the proximity probe. Here's a couple suggestions, yo. When I upgraded to 24V the proximity probe had a much greater range than when it was running off 12V. That's a fact, jack. Make your adjustments with the probe and spec out your shizzle. Now El Scorpion is your ally.

I really hope this "thing" makes being a maker for someone else a little easier, like all the "things" I've printed that have aided me. Have fun, guys.

author: Ceasar1010

title: Sir Pigglesby (a most noble piggy bank)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Sir Pigglesby is a multi part 3D printable piggy bank with a threaded stopper - he's about 25cm long fully assembled. The colours chosen and the painting of Sir Pigglesby are simply my recommendations and can of course be changed as wished. All of Sir Pigglesby was printed on a Prusa i3.
​
As is the tradition with my other fantasy models, Sir Pigglesby has a little (and possibly rather silly) backstory:

"Sir Pigglesby is a brave knight who serves in the army of the Sun. He wears a magic belt given to him by a Moon princess in thanks for joining her on a quest to rescue her parents from an army of Trolls. The belt (which bears the crescent insignia of the Moon Kingdom) enables Sir Pigglesby to carry an infinite number of objects without being hampered by bulk or weight. Only the chosen wearer can release the objects and as he is a noble, honest and loyal pig, he is in great demand to transport valuable items on the most dangerous missions."

There is quite a real life story attached to the creation of Sir Pigglesby. I've not been around much this and last year (from a free downloadable model standpoint), either due to professional commitments(for the first part of the 2016) and the second part(and still ongoing), helping my Louisiana family recover from a devastating flood and the serious illness of a close family member. Due to these personal commitments, I have not taken on any new commissions, but in order to "keep my hand in" artistically speaking (and to keep up spirits), I designed this friendly and brave piggy. I imagine him as a merry little fellow who would make anyone smile even on the worst days and would protect those close to him, no matter the danger.

I give you Sir Pigglesby - I hope you enjoy printing him as much I did designing him.

This instructable will tell you what to do:

https://www.instructables.com/id/The-Assembly-of-Sir-Pigglesby/

NOTE: coin_slot_v2.stl uploaded with a 33mm x 10mm slot size. If a coin can't get through that then it's too big for Sir Pigglesby:-)

NOTE: Please also see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2283693

All the beautiful filament used for this print of sir Pigglesby(except for the pink used for his head) was made by Proto Pasta.

http://www.proto-pasta.com/
Blood, sweat and tears in Blender and sometimes in a FEMA trailer..

description.text:
Based off of designs already on Thingiverse, I bring you the Colt Peacemaker Spinner.
Now, before people start getting out their calipers and telling me it is not to scale... relax, it's just a bad ass looking spinner toy loosely based off of the Peacemaker's cylinder.

When printed at 1:1 it is 30 mm tall and has a diameter of 56 mm. You might be able to place with it's size some but it also may end up fusing together and making it immovable.

Layer Height: .15 mm

Perimeters: 2

Infill: 35%
Supports: No
Raft: No
Scale: 1:1
Netfabb'd: Yes

Get it moving with an allen wrench by hand at first then once it moves some what freely, put the straight end of the allen wrench in a drill and go to town. 3 in 1 oil also helps a ton, when combined with the drill.

title: Gear Charm for your Crocs™ (includes blank base)

description.text:
I have a problem. I am seeking ways to put gears onto anything. This obsession will run its course sometime, but I do not see the end in sight, just now.

I have included an updated blank base so that you can make your own custom soft shoe embellishments. Simply attach whatever you are currently obsessed with. You can either print your charm separately and glue it onto the base, or bring the STL into a designer and mesh it all up.

The original sat too low on the croc, and the gear was too easily popped off, so I ended up losing gears all over the place. I have improved on that with the latest version.

description.text:
UPDATES!
5/14/17- Was notified that the brake is a bit too strong for some printers, Created two more versions. P1 Clearance is .1 more clearance and P2 clearance has .2 more. Comment if you would like to see more clearance than that.

Results

4/19/17- After the initial installation of this i aligned by X carriage perfectly horizontal by measuring with a digital caliper from the X rods to the Z axis stepper mounts.
Since then, the carriage has not changed one bit. I have not had to adjust my auto level sensor, and before this mod i had to adjust it every day.
This is the best mod i have ever done for my printer, and its super easy!

Just a tip!

After you install this, level your X carriage from the frame to the x axis rods, its very important that you level it to the rods, then make a mark on your stepper motor shaft collar and a mark on the Z-Brake with a sharpie, and you will never need to use the caliper again, and you can double check that they stay aligned by moving the Z axis up or down until the marks line up!

What Fer?

As soon as I printed other upgrade parts for my X axis carriage to line up the Z threaded rods I noticed that the entire carriage started to fall down when powered off, the weight of the X carriage was turning the Z axis rods very slowly overnight, and getting out of level. Anet must of intentionally
misaligned those rods to create some friction. If you have this issue too, here's a fix for you!

This will stop your Z Axis from falling down when your printer is off, but doesn't prevent your z-axis from moving, because your motors overpower it.

Install

if you have a squashed first layer make sure you clean that off of where it rubs on the shaft collar or else it will cause a LOT more drag than its intended to.

You might also run into an issue with too much drag, in this case the Z steppers will be unable to overcome this brake, you can either sand down the breaking surface, or adjust the potentiometer for your Z axis until your motors can overpower it, alternatively you can adjust the scaling or the included fusion 360 project to fit your printer or application.

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel, Gear Down For What?https://www.youtube.com/c/GearDownForWhat

comments.author: jkrollin

comments.text:
This upgrade is not needed. Well every rod upgrade isn't needed if you mount the rod and coupler the correct way.
The Z wobbling happens because all the rods come bent from factory, some more than the others, but all come bent, and it is impossible to get it 100% straight. That's why the couplers act like a spring for when the Y axis starts "dancing", it compensates and doesn't force the Z axis to move around, preventing the wobbling.
The stepper motor and the rod must be inserted to the coupler only 5 mm, leaving a gap between the stepper and the rod. If they touch you mounted it wrong and the springy action of the coupler will not do its job. The rod must go trough the top hole and be free without any "upgrade".

print_settings.Notes:: These are relatively simple solid shapes as far as 3D models go, and printing with infill should give the necessary support for the top layers. Printing without enough infill can lead to irregularities on the top surfaces.

description.text:
The top surface of these shapes are defined by the functions over the x and y intervals:

1) f(x,y) = Aarcsinh(x-y)cos(xy/3) ; {x,y} 0 -> 2*pi

2) f(x,y) = Asech(y)sin(xy) ; {x,y} -pi -> pi

In these functions, A is an arbitrary real number that multiplies the surface but does not affect their general shape. The solid shapes printed out are a representation of the volume attained by integrating the functions over x and y.

Notes:

These are relatively simple solid shapes as far as 3D models go, and printing with infill should give the necessary support for the top layers. Printing without enough infill can lead to irregularities on the top surfaces.
The surfaces were defined and converted to a 3D file format using Wolfram Mathematica software. Mathematica supports a datatype referred to as a "mesh-region" which can be easily exported as .STL

I decided to try my hand at designing a fidget spinner. I went with a simple 3 lobe design. This will fit a standard 8mm x 22mm x 7mm bearing, as found in inline skates.

This was designed using OpenSCAD.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I've added a heated bed to my Printrbot Simple Metal, so I could print in ABS. The pictured print is using Gizmo Dark Blue filament. I printed at 240 degrees C and kept the bed at 85 degrees C.
On my Printrbot with 20% infill and 0.2mm layer height, this prints in about 45 minutes. Changing to 0.1mm layer height raises print time above 2 hours, but is worth it if you want a nice finish.

Adding Bearings

After printing you can clean up the print if you want, but mostly it's ready to add the bearings.
You need four bearings for a 3-lobe spinner. Place the spinner on a hard flat surface and set a bearings level on one of the holes. Press hard using a small hard surface like a flat piece of wood. Be careful not to press on the walls of the bearing as you may damage it.
Repeat for the other 3 bearings and you are done.

Print Some Hub Caps

It is useful to have a couple of caps that fit in the center bearing and let you hold the bearing without putting any friction on it.
I printed out two of the caps from this thing post:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1800902

Much thanks to sLpFhaWK (https://www.thingiverse.com/sLpFhaWK) for his excellent work.

Using Math in OpenSCAD

I included the OpenSCAD file I used to generate the STL files on this thing. You can alter the variables to change the lobe diameter, length of the arms, and other stuff. I commented the code pretty well so hopefully you can follow it.
The model takes a really long time to render. I think I have some weird math in their. Some values for the variables can kick up an error during rendering, but I have provided comments noting safe values to use.

description.text: This stand contains a place where you can drop your phone into, and a place for your powerbank. The powerbank section of the stand can be used with a square or circular base, but it works best with a square base. It works best as it was designed for a square-base powerbank.

Why was the stand created?

This stand came to be as I realized that I required a stand for my powerbank (also spelled powerpack) when I fly on airplanes. The turbulence effects my phone's charging, so I created this: the Powerbank and Phone Stand.

Does it work?

Yes. It definitely works.

How does it work?

Since I have a phone with the connector on the bottom, like an iPhone or most Android phones, I drop my phone onto the stand bottom up and it allows me to plug the cord in. Same goes for the powerbank.

description.text:
I designed this mausoleum for Frostgrave (specifically for the scenario "The Mausoleum" which requires a small square or rectangular building at least 6 inches on a side with a door on each of the 4 sides. I ran into another person's treatment of the specific building I modeled this after, the Moorhead Mausoleum. The building was perfect, but the designs were not publicly available. This building can be used for any fantasy gaming purpose, not just Frostgrave. My design comes with the ability to insert either doors or windows (like the real building) in any of the 4 cardinal sides.

Includes a OpenForge 2.0 bases for magnetic and OpenLOCK systems.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

I got the idea for this piece from a very similar piece based off the same real world mausoleum. It was published in the lead adventurers forum by TabletopToReign. I found the inspiration, the Morehead Mausoleum in Allegheny Cemetary, Pittsburgh. I gave the mausoleum my own spin on it.

Moorhead Mausoleum History

The Moorhead Mausoleum, which has underground crypts, was surely the grandest tomb in the Cemetery before the construction of the Ford mausoleum (Section 1) three decades later. It stood in splendid isolation, surrounded by a heavy stone fence as Gothic as itself. The style has an unusual fantasy about it, almost as if some imperial tent had been reproduced in sandstone. The Moorhead for whom this mausoleum was built appears to have been James Kennedy Moorhead, d. 1884, a Corporator of the Cemetery who was a Pennsylvania Canal operator, builder of engineering works, and president of the Monongahela Navigation Company, which canalized the river of that name. (from Allegheny Cemetery)

Supplies

3d printed parts

  • Dome
  • Entrance 1 (4x) (print with the top face down for best results
  • Entrance 2 (4x)
  • Entrance 3 (8x)
  • Mausoleum Wall (4x)
  • 4 doors or windows, any mix you prefer

Paint

  • Brown primer (I use Krylon Fusion Ultra Flat Camouflage)
  • Burnt Sienna (Americana)
  • Raw Sienna (Americana)
  • Honey Brown (Americana)
  • Fawn (Americana)
  • Desert Sand (Americana)
  • Sepia Wash (Vallejo Game Color)
  • Umber Wash (Vallejo Game Color)
  • Black Wash (Vallejo Game Color)
  • Adamantine Black (Reaper Master Series)
  • Old Pewter (Reaper Master Series)
  • Old Bronze (Reaper Master Series)
  • Spruce Green (Reaper Master Series HD)
  • Sapphire Blue (Reaper Master Series)
  • Liquitex Matte Medium
  • Water

Other Supplies

  • 1.75 mm filament, 8 short lengths about 3/4"
  • Cyanoacrylate glue (super glue)
Prime the pieces with dark brown primer. I love the Krylon Fusion paints, they are super flat and bind to plastic really well. Hit the stone areas with medium coverage of Burnt Sienna. You want to make sure the deep areas still show through with the dark brown. Now do a lighter coverage of Raw Sienna. Not quite a drybrush, but make sure the paintbrush is not particularly full of paint. Now drybrush with Honey brown. This is intended to be a highlight, so you want to focus on it ending up on the upturned edges of the piece. I do this by only moving the brush down against the part. (Optional) Now use fawn to pick out about 5 blocks per piece. Drybrush the fawn on and onto the same brick on the reverse side. Pick different bricks for each of the 4 parts. (Optional) Now use a sepia wash and pick out 5 more bricks. Cover the whole brick with the wash on front and back. This is called glazing. We are using the wash to tint the entire brick. (Optional) Finally glaze 5 more random bricks with a brown wash. Brown and sepia are similar, but the hue is still different, and the bricks will give some variation. Use a black wash inside the grate at the bottom (Optional) Highlight the stone embelishments (the arches, pillars and base of the niche) with a mix of Desert Sand and Honey Brown Use a very dark metallic on the grate itself. I used Adamantium Black. Highlight the grate with a lighter metallic. I chose to also go for a more dull color in Aged Pewter to show the age. Paint the tracery on the top, the rods and the small symbol above the niche with a bronze paint. Here I use Old Bronze. Mix a green and a blue to create a turquoise. Then add a wash medium and some water. I use equal parts Liquitex Matte Medium and water to make the wash. If you don't have that, you can use water and a little rubbing alcohol to make the wash. The alcohol will make it so the wash also sticks to surfaces instead of just going for the crevices. I took my green which was already close to a turquoise and dry brushed the raised surfaces to get more verdegris on the metal.. Glue some short lengths of filament into two of the walls. Glue two sides together, making sure that the filament sides are oriented so you can glue the two halves together. The filament acts as a strengthener to keep the bond between sides strong. Glue the two halves together and clamp. If using the floors, glue them into two halves and wait to dry. Then glue the two sides together. Flip over and glue the pillars in the corners. The pillars are painted the same way as the rest. Glue the painted roof and arches to the building, but *not* the pillars. There's an outline on the building of where these two pieces should be glued. I found it works out better if you glue the arches first and then the roof. Paint the door and door arch (glue 2 back to back) with the krylon flat dark brown Hit the wood on the door with Burnt Umber Do a lighter layer with Milk Chocolate. I'm keeping the browns a different hue from the stone to make it clear that this is wood. Dry brush with Honey Brown I used the Aged Pewter on all the metal parts and on the two sides. Then lined around the metal parts with a black wash. Paint the arch and the top of the door like the rest of the stonework. Slide the decorative arch in, then the door. Don't glue, this is made to be able to hold windows (like 3 sides of the real mausoleum) or a wall. Both of which I plan on releasing later. Changelog
  • Dec 13, 2017 - Terrain4print fixed up some bad geometry in Entrance_1.stl, thanks!

remixed_from.author: funbart
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi B+ with RemotePi Board Plus 2015 case

description.text:
I took funbarts design for a case that supports the remotepi board sold at http://www.msldigital.com/ and made a few modifications. It's not perfect, but I'm publishing it for anyone who wants to customize it for their needs. If I ever reprint it, I'm going to try to blend the tallest side on the bottom into the curve of the top of the case better.

  • cut out a hole for the ir receiver (for the version of the board with the attached ir receiver)
  • didn't have any 2.5 mm screws so I added pins to hold the pi and some tabs for friction to hold the case together
  • covered the old power supply input
  • added a thin cover over the led, my print is white and the lights shine through it
  • covered the hole for the camera cable (I didn't have a need for it)

I had to sand down the pins after printing and enlarged the pin holes with a small screw driver to get it to snap together.

print_settings.Notes:: No need for support if using a part cooling fan.

title: Apple Watch Travel Charging Stand and Cord Organizer

description.text:
This stand is perfect for your Apple Watch if you're a traveler and want to have an easy way to keep your Apple Watch charging puck cable organized on the go. Easily wrap the chord around the stand, slide it into any of the many grooves along the stand's base, and throw it in your bag and go!

These grooves also come in handy if you want to shorten the charging cable whilst on top of your nightstand.

Just print it out, feed the magnetic charging usb cable through the slot right under the circular cutout, squeeze in the circular charging puck, drop your apple watch down, wrap the cable around if you so desire and you're good to go!

Features:

  • Slot for inductive charging USB cable
  • Circular cutout for inductive charging puck
  • Hole behind charging puck to push out charging puck if needed
  • Slot to run cable under stand that exits to back of the stand
  • Slot for Apple Watch to sit on it's side for night stand mode
  • Designed for 42mm Watch but does work with 38mm version

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 μm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No need for support if using a part cooling fan.

description.text:
Does the world need another AA battery container design? Arguably, it does not. But when I was looking for one, I did not find one with a slide lid and openings so that the contents are visible. So I designed one despite the fact that there are probably too many similar designs already. If you like it, great! If not, well, there are plenty of other choices out there.

13Apr2017 UPDATE: I have added Version 2 of the lid for the original box. This one has a little nub to lock it in place when the lid is slid closed. You might prefer this one to the original.

15Apr2017 UPDATE: I've spun a new version that's a but more compact (batteries don't rattle around quite so much. Use the V3 files for this version.

description.text:
I really like this badge/logo. It was too big for my printer though.
So I cut it in half and added another support rail at the bottom.
I placed tiny 1mm holes into the ends of the support rails. A 1mm hole won't print right, not on my printer anyway, I used them as a guide. I drilled them out with a 0.8mm drill bit, then I straightened and cut up a paper clip and inserted it into the holes. After I trimmed the paper clips to fit, I added some super glue and stuck them together. (I printed this in ABS) Plenty strong.
I have some top layer scaring so I'll probably run the face on a belt sander, then maybe some 220 wet sand to smooth it off.
THANK YOU!!!

description.text:
This is a tool caddy for the Prusa provided tools in the Original Prusa i3 MK2(S) kits.

This caddy allows easy storage and access to your tools for making adjustments/repairs as needed.

Placement for the tool caddy is in the corner above the Rambo housing.

There are now 2 versions of the Tool Caddy:

  • The original version allows the allen wrenches to go all the way through the caddy. This can cause an issue in very rare situations with the longer 2.5mm allen when the X axis is at 0 and the Z axis is above 200.
  • The 2nd version limits the allen wrenches depth in the Tool Caddy and staggers the allen wrenches. This resolves the very rare times that are described above. I have also moved the needle nose slot closer to the corner edge.

Note: After printing this in various configurations, I have determined that the best way to print is in the orientation that it will attach to the frame. So this means supports would be needed in this orientation. When you slice it, I recommend using the option to only use the base for supports. This will move the supports on the overhand that holds it to the frame away from the lower locking ledge.

The STL file should already be aligned the way it should be printed. Recommended first layer is the logo side down.

Update 1:

Reduced the lower ledge bump. The original was a bit too large and was very difficult to snap in to place

Update 2:

Found out the Needle Nose Pliers slot had too thin of walls. I increased it to a 2mm wall and increased the size to better accomodate the pliers. Also added another ridge to better support the top part of the caddy.

description.text:
Still working out some kinks with this air gate but so far so good! In the original version (pictured here) the lower legs were separate from the short vertical sections which worked fine but there was too much flex in the middle of the "Y" connector with moderate wind.

In the version uploaded it allows the vertical posts go all the way through the "Y" connector for added stiffness. I haven't tested this yet so let me know your results. This will also save setup time because you can leave the "Y" and elbow connector attached to the long sections. Connections are tight but stay together very well. Printed in TPU for flex and durability. Add some pool noodles to soften the blow when you smash 'em with your quad.

If you make two gates with these sizes, there will be no waste.

3/4" SCH40 PVC
(2) 7.5'
(4) 2.5'

Makes one gate with a 4'4" wide by 5' high opening.

Use this to configure your own size:
http://www.had2know.com/academics/hexagon-measurement-calculator.html

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30%

Notes:

No need for fine detail here. Just need to be functional. They take a while to print so if you have a larger nozzle I'd recommend that. I used a .5mm. May even jump up to a .6 for the next batch.

title: Standoff for Heat Bed Power Module Expansion Board (MOSFET) for Monoprice Maker Select, Wanhao i3, Cocoon Create
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATED: New and improved and addtional configurations

You may need to rotate the model to fit on your bed.

There are multiple models so that you can choose your configuration. The left configuration seems to be the most popular. If you want the MOSFET board on the left, pick the model marked left.

Probably everyone with a Monoprice Maker Select, Wanhao i3, or Cocoon Create who uses the heated bed should consider moving the high current and heat off of the main Melzi board to ensure long life of the main board.

The Heat Bed Power Module Expansion (MOSFET) board achieves that and is easy to install:

There are various sellers of this board, available from multiple sources such as Amazon, eBay, and Ali Express.

Some people are printing standoffs and taping or hot gluing them in. I wanted something a bit easier and more secure. This standoff fits over two of the existing standoffs for the main board, and so it is firmly screwed in place.

Parts needed (single MOSFET board):

  • 4 x M3x5mm 0.5mm pitch screws (can use up to 6mm length)
  • 4 x nylon washers
  • 14awg or 12awg wire

The threads on the standoff are M3 0.5mm, the same as the original standoffs for the main board. Buy 4 M3X5mm (0.5mm pitch) screws and 4 nylon washers. You'll use the 4 screws and washers to mount the expansion board to the standoff.

Purchase Links:
MOSFET board
14awg Wire
Ring Terminals

Installation Instructions:

  1. Remove the SD card from your printer's control box
  2. Disassemble the control box
  3. Remove the existing Melzi main board from the control box (keep the screws and washers)
  4. Screw the MOSFET expansion board to the printed standoff using the 4 new washers and screws
  5. Place the larger, unthreaded, holes of the printed standoff over the middle two standoffs built into the control box cover for the main board. (Note: You can install the standoff feet up or feet down.)
  6. Screw the main board back in over top, using the original 4 washers and screws
  7. Use the wiring diagram for your MOSFET board (provided by the seller) to finish the installation

Be sure to remove the SD card before you remove the main board to ensure that you don't damage the SD slot when removing the board.

Read more about the problem here:
The Melzi Problem, or, Why Did My Wanhao i3 Duplicator Catch on Fire?

Control box disassembly video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXQ1gAid17Y

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Don't forget to rotate the standoff to fit on the bed.

title: RAMPS to MKS BASE 1.5 Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Decided I have had enough of replacing RAMPS/Arduino combos, so I decided to try out the MKS BASE V1.5. Looks good so far, but needed to mount it in the Robo3D R1. It is made to mount, not to the Arduino/RAMPS holes, but to the extra holes that are also underneath.

The one picture with the board is just for reference to see the size comparison.

I have printed, but not yet fitted yet, so more updates to come.

UPDATE 4/10/17: Board didn't fit right in the sideways orientation; blocked the power blocks. Redesigned for 'vertical' orientation. Will require internal usb cable.

UPDATE 4/12/17: Redrew the adapter to fit the board sideways. Laying it flat would require cutting some of the internal support wall, so I angled the mount so that it holds it at roughly a 16 degree angle, allowing the USB cable to clear the wall. Of course, if you print connected to an OctoPi (or computer), you will need to leave the cable connected internally and routed out of the case through the existing hole.

I added a mount for a 40mm fan to blow across the right side of the board, which is where the stepper drivers reside.

More pictures to come after mounting and test fitting.

UPDATE 4/14/17: Not quite enough room for the fan, so I played around a bit more, and then change the slot/mount. Top (which becomes the bottom) are 'bumps to rest in the holes, while the bottom are open for screws, zip ties, whatever.

description.text:
Inspired by Google's 2017 April Fools "Google Gnome" project at
https://store.google.com/magazine/gnome
The pieces just slide over your Google Home device. Unfortunately, functionality of your Google Home will be impacted: you can no longer see the lights on top, the microphones are under the hat (although I included a few holes to let the sound come through), and the touch surface on top (volume and stop) is no longer accessible.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

Default

Notes:

Print without support. There is a small overhang at the top of the sleeve where the ledge in the back has no support, but that can be ignored as it will be hidden by the hat.

For a regular Google Home, only print "Gnome sleeve" and "Gnome hat". The sleeve just slides on - check for alignment of the mute button. Squeeze the hat a bit and insert into the top of the sleeve - no glue needed.

For the small gnome, print all four pieces. I recommend black for the lower body, white for the upper body, blue for the sleeve (jacket), and red for the hat.

Update 4/16/2017: I redesigned the small gnome body pieces to be hollow, and fit together with a snug fit, without glue.

Update 8/12/2017: I uploaded updated sleeve and hat files for the small gnome. The original ones were too thin, creating some artifacts during printing.
For the small gnome, consider glueing the hat on.

title: Easter Egg Maker 2017 Symmetry
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Rev. C 4/14/2017 - Added some example scripts, .stl files and images to show just a few examples of what is possible.
Rev. B 4/12/2017 - Added "twist" parameter to rotate lattice over length of egg for spiral like effects
Rev. A 4/10/2017 - Added wallpaper groups and fixed a few bugs
NOTE: Customizer might timeout if you make the resolution too high. In this case, you can still make your egg by downloading OpenSCAD and working offline. I find it much faster to work offline anyway, plus you can use your own objects as the feature use in the decoration on the egg. Have FUN above all and Happy Easter!

Generates many Easter Egg patterns by setting a few customizable parameters. Includes "wallpaper group" (9 of 17) tiling options for many interesting effects. Allows printing of the decoration and egg separately for dual extrusion (assuming the geometry you specify will support it). Will make hollow eggs with the option to bisect and add a joiner to make a reusable container. Can be decorated on the inside or made smooth.

Also, please check out my other Easter Egg makers from the past 3 years under "Remixed From".

Includes the following customizable parameters:

/ [Decoration] /

//Add or subtract decoration from egg (use feature depth to control amount)?
operation="subtract"; //[subtract,add,decoration_only,egg_only]

//Choose a feature to repeat?
feature="square"; //[sphere,star,dot,triangle,square,diamond,pentagon,hexagon,octagon]

//Set the relative size of the feature
size_of_feature=100; //[1:250]

//Number of horizontal loops; impacts pattern and render time (for larger values, use offline)
ucount=8; //[3:16]

//Number of vertical loops; impacts pattern and reander time (for larger values, use offline)
vcount=8; //[3:16]

//Set the relative depth of the feature
feature_depth=10; //

//Set the feature start angle (values like 0, 15, 30 and 45 work best)
start_angle=0; //

//How much feature rotation over the length of the egg (0 for none)?
feature_rotation=0; //

//Vary feature size (yes give a better appearance)?
proportional="yes"; //[yes,no]

/ placement (wallpaper group) 9 of 17 /
//Select a wallpaper group to control symmetry (google wallpaper group for more information)
group="p1"; //[p1,p2,pm,pg,cm,pmm,pmg,pgg,p4]

//Set some X offset to control the effect of the wallpaper group on symmetrical features (%).
Xoffset=0; //[0:100]

//Set some Y offset to control the effect of the wallpaper group on symmetrical features (%).
Yoffset=0; //[0:100]

//Set some X scaling to control the effect of the wallpaper group on symmetrical features (%)
Xscaling=100; //[10:100]

//Set some Y scaling to control the effect of the wallpaper group on symmetrical features (%)
Yscaling=100; //[10:100]

/ [Size and Shape] /
//Length of the egg (mm)?.
egg_length=60; //[30:200]

//What shape egg? (use 7 for a hen egg; 0 for a sphere; 100 for a blimp)
egg_shape=7; //[0:100]

//What percentage of the interior should be hollow (0 for totally solid)
interior=85; //[0:95]

//Do you want the inside to be smooth or decorated? (hollow bisected eggs only)
inside="smooth"; //[smooth,decorated]

/ [Printing] /
//Do you want it bisected? (IMPORTANT: YES for printing, NO during preview.)
bisect="no"; //[yes,no]

//Do you want to add a joiner to hold the egg together? (hollow bisected eggs only)
joiner="attached"; //[attached,detached,none]

//Set the spacing between parts on the build plate in mm
spacing=2; //[2:10]

title: Adjustable NEMA17 stepper mount with clocking adjustment

description.text:
Updated
-As per suggestions, I have added adjustable clocking without the need to rescrew the mounting plate to the printer baseplate.
-Also added four notches to help with installation for those who like to be precise :)

Single Z-axis stepper motor upgrade intended for, but not limited to, the Folgertech FT-5 printer.

Fully adjustable motor position for belt tensioning via loosening of stepper mounting screws. Clocking is also adjustable by turning the mounting plate to desired position.

Installation requires cutting a 3" hole (by means of 3" hole saw in base plate). To mount unit, place in newly cut hole and the unit will center itself with its guide ring, fasten with 6x #6x1/2" pan head wood screws.

This plate is intended to be used with a dual GT2 belt pulley.

description.text:
As most owners of the Maker Select V2 have probably noticed, the provided spool holder is too thin for most filament spools. This design extends the provided holder by about 2cm, making it plenty big for most rolls. It has a semi-rounded top for low friction against the roll, a key for ensuring the part stays in place, and a flared bottom to fit snugly into the stock filament holder.

To install, unscrew the nut holding the stock holder, turn the stock holder over, and slide the printed part into the groove from the side. Insert the key into the hole in the printed holder.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2VMW6Hz3k5f

USB charger for Pentax D-Li90 batteries. I've been using previous versions of these to recharge my phone (which I use as a GPS) on backpacking trips, but the older versions aren't working as reliably with newer phones. This circuit seems to work better and is much smaller. I usually top off my phone with the batteries when they don't have enough charge for my camera, but I haven't checked to see how well that works with this converter.

Uses a step down circuit with USB Port*. A USB power meter* can be helpful for testing.

Ruby Red and Sapphire Blue Translucent PETG from Atomic Filament

*affiliate link

Small housing for a end stop switch to be used as a filament runout sensor.

Once printend, insert a microswitch based endstop and ensure that the orientation is such that filament can pass through from top to bottom.

Make sure to insert the switch as far as possible without triggering the switch. Once in place, use hot glue to secure it.

The endstop can be attached to a GPIO on a raspberry pi and used with the filament sensor reloaded plugin for octoprint available here: https://github.com/kontakt/Octoprint-Filament-Reloaded

title: Jean Gordon's Carving: One Surface! Double Moebius Strip

description.text:
This amazing carving, only one surface, is my favourite of my late mother's carvings. Blows my mind that this could be carved from one piece of wood. This probably indicates a great lack of aesthetic sense - or that I'm an engineer! OK - a tautology, I admit.
Anyway...
I found this very difficult to scan. In the end I 'bolted it together' which can be seen in one of the photos. Scanned with an Einscan S (Scanmaster Plus).
The scanning shortcomings - and the bolts - meant quite a lot of work in Meshmixer.
Sliced in Simplify 3D and printed full size on a Prusa Original i3 Mk2 in PLA.
Also printed half size on Kodama Trinus in PLA and 64% size in a Robox in ABS.

description.text:
This is Ikea JANSJÖ LED lamp mount for Vertex K8400 printer. I removed the clamp and permanently installed the lamp at the front of the left side panel. All parts are printed with 0.2mm resolution, 15% infill and touchbed support.
You will need to replace 8 M5 x 12mm socket cup screws with longer screws (20mm, or 25mm).
I powered up the lamp from my 24VDC power supply for heated bed. Ikea sells this lamp with 2 different power supplies. One has 4VDC output, another 7VDC. My lamp came with 7VDC power supply. I used 100 Ohm 5 Watt ceramic resistor to drop the voltage from 24V to 6.3V.
STL file contains all 6 parts. Separate them in Repetier Host before printing.

title: Flipping Funnel for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
The Flipping Funnel for the Original Prusa i3 MK2.
So easy to clean or change the nozzle! Just flip the funnel out of the way and in you go!
Or flip it aside when printing nylon or any filament where the fan is off. Now you can see what you're printing!

It's just two parts, the flipping funnel and the extruder cover (plus a 3mm x 25mm screw and nut).

I just uploaded an older design which incorporates a catch. I found the catch was unnecessary, but someone indicated they might want such a thing so I offer it. At the risk of repeating myself, the catch introduced complexity without any real benefit, plus it is a bit trickier to print.

I also have the printed parts for sale at my Etsy store.

Check out my Floating LED Light. It mounts to the extruder and travels along, lighting and eliminating that shadow underneath.

More information at Maximpulse.com.

Youtube video:
https://youtu.be/NTRVL_3ijIg

Prusa

30% or more

Notes:

I have printed this in PLA, ABS, and PETG and they all perform fine for me.
I usually have 4 perimeters and 3 top and bottom solid layers.

Requires a 3 mm x 25 mm screw and nut.

comments.author: ryanneufeld

comments.text:
I replied yesterday, but since then my reply has been stuck in "flagged for moderation". Sigh.
Anyway, all I wrote was that both a "nozzle" and a "funnel" are bad words for this part for two reasons.
First, the part where the melted filament comes out is also called a nozzle. Having two parts with the same name invites confusion.
Second, both "nozzle" and "funnel" refer to round things.
Nozzle: a cylindrical or round spout at the end of a pipe, hose, or tube, used to control a jet of gas or liquid.
Funnel: a tube or pipe that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for guiding liquid or powder into a small opening.
So both are bad words for this object.
The best term I could find was "angle head stack" (a kind of duct fitting) but that doesn't exactly roll off the tongue.
So this isn't a nozzle. It isn't a funnel. Oh well. We both get to be wrong.
comments.author: ryanneufeld

comments.text:
I understand. Prusa calls such a piece a nozzle, too.
But the part the melted filament comes out of is called a nozzle, too, so that can lead to confusion.
I settled on calling it funnel, just to differentiate it. "Air director" was too cumbersome as were other words or phrases.

title: NodeMCU Multisensor - temp, humidity, light, motion, RGB Led

description.text:
UPDATE 10 JUN 2017 - I added a second version of my enclosure that moves the DHT22 sensor outside the case, removes the standoff for the LDR sensor, and adds a pocket for the LED. This should reduce most of the high temperatures being reported by the board and the removal of the standoff allows you to use either the TEMT600 sensor or photoresistor module. A dab of hot glue can help hold everything in place until you can snap the case together.

Video Tutorial - https://youtu.be/jpjfVc-9IrQ

This enclosure is for DIY Multisensor that can be built using a NodeMCU 1.0 ESP8266 development board. It works great with Home Assistant - my favorite open-source, home automation platform.

no soldering and no breadboards required!

The code for the NodeMCU development board was written in the ArduinoIDE and is availible here.

A few people have reported that the floating PIR sensor issue is back. If it happens, wrap the PIR module in electrical tape, then aluminum foil, and then electrical tape again. Using the tape will make sure you don't short anything out with the foil on either the module or other components in the system.

Supported Features Include

  • DHT22 temperature sensor
  • DHT 22 humdidity sensor
  • AM312 PIR motion sensor
  • photoresistor or TEMT600 light sensor
  • RGB led with support for color, flash, fade, and transition
  • Over-the-Air (OTA) upload from the ArduinoIDE

Parts List

Amazon Prime (fast shipping)

  • NodeMCU 1.0
  • DHT22 Module
  • LDR Photoresistor Module
    OR
  • TEMT6000
  • Power Supply
  • Common Cathode RGB Led
  • Header Wires
  • Mini PIR Sensor

Aliexpress (long shipping = cheap prices)

  • NodeMCU 1.0
  • DHT22 Module
  • LDR Photoresistor Module
    OR
  • TEMT6000
  • Power Supply
  • Common Cathode RGB Led
  • Header Wires
  • Mini PIR Sensor

author: c4sfer

title: Citroën Xsara II - USB Holder + Dummy button + Window regulator dummy button

description.text:
This is a button-shaped USB cable holder, designed to fit my Alpine CDA-117RI USB cable, made to go to the horizontal lower panel buttons (see pictures). Might be compatible with other USB devices.

For Xsara cars without the 3 buttons (only the middle one) you'll have to buy a 3 button panel and print the button cache to hide the missing button (or buy a dummy one). On the 3 button version, you'll have to remove the original dummy button.

Contents :

  • 1 USB button : print this once. Please note this is the part you'll see, so you might want to print this in higher quality.
  • 1 USB holder : print this twice (once is enough, but it is not designed this way). This part goes behind the panel, and will fit into the standard squared holder. NO GLUE NEEDED !
  • 1 filled button : print this if you need to hide an empty button. You'll have to glue this.
  • 1 filled window control button : print this twice if you need to hide unused window regulator buttons (for Coupés models with 2 windows, if you have to change the panel by the 4 windows version to get the 3 horizontal buttons, like mine - see pictures). You'll have to glue this.

Installation instructions for USB button - no glue needed. Make sure all parts fit well before assembling :)
1.Remove the panel, remove the dummy button (if needed), and pass the USB cable through the car's inner squared button holder.
2.Put the USB connector into the USB button.
3.Put one side of the USB holder into the car's inner squared button holder.
4.On the USB cable, put the other side of the USB holder, and push everything into the car's inner squared button holder.

  1. Put back the panel, make sure to align the button with the panel.
  2. Test if there's no move, and if everything is strong enough when you push and pull your USB device.

I printed the whole parts in PLA, but ABS is advised because of car's heat, and USB cable/device heat.

author: Percevalio

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with the small diameter up, supports for the big end.

title: Rotary Engine Pilot Bearing & Seal Tool (RX-7 12A Engine)

description.text:
I made this real fast because I was installing a clutch in my RX-7 and needed to replace the pilot bearing and seal. I decided I wanted a driver to hold the bearing and set it the correct amount into the eccentric shaft squarely leaving room for the pilot bearing seal.

Place the bearing on the small end of the tool and drive until the large diameter is flush with the end of the 20mm bore in the eccentric shaft. This sets the bearing depth.

Place the seal around the small end of the tool, and insert it into the bearing already in place. Drive the seal until the seal diameter is flush with the end of the eccentric shaft.

By extending into the bearing already in place, it will help drive the seal squarely into the eccentric shaft.

Do not try and install the seal and bearing at the same time! The seal will be crushed!

Might work for the 13B engines, but I have no way to verify. So long as the taper depth in the end of the eccentric shaft is the same as the 12A I have it should work to set the bearing to the proper depth (5mm -0.0/+2.0mm below the start of the 20mm ID after the taper).

Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

This Mario Bros planter is the third and last member of the geek planter collection. This planter has single and dual extrusion versions. Also, you can find it with or without holes (perfect for your office desk).

In this video, I explain the design process and some tips when assembling it: https://youtu.be/TRpGZDM_oW4

The filament used for this design is Innofil3D PLA (Gold and White PLA). It can be purchased here: https://www.innofil3d.com

I'd like to thank all my supporters and patrons, with your help I've been able to create this project. The Patreon MVPs for this project are 3D Maker Noob, 3D Printing Stuff, MatterHackers, Filaments.directory, Dattas Moonchaser, MidnightGiant, Andrew Howat, Didier Klein and David Kessler!

comments.text: I thought I'd be able to print the two files separately for different colors, but I now see how the details is all one object. Would be cool to have them separated then they could be printed and snapped into place.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

I have a cheaper Chinese Hot tub and have an issue where the drain level is too low so when 4 people sit in the tub, water drains out and the next time 1 or 2 people sit in the tub it is too shallow. not to mention all the extra water and heating needed to replace the lost water.

I have designed this drain to raise the drains water level my about 1" which will resolve this issue.

i thought i would share if anyone else has this specific issue. the drain cap that this clips onto is 81.252mm in diameter and i have sized this to be 1mm oversize as i have printed in ABS to allow for shrinkage.
